column4: hi i am very new to this os and i am confused as hell are there any dedicated rooms here where i can ask a few questions please?
just ask the questions, providing as much info as you know like ubuntu version, hardware that is not working, what you last did...
for all intent and purpose, there is no need to 'defarg' in linux.
if you have the 'update-manager' installed, then it will show a 'orange blob' in your tool bar when you need to upgrade. click it, and it will do the upgrade.
most software updates from time to time, but if you get something 'hot-off-the-press', it may have bugs, so it is best to get the version that is supported for your ubuntu release.
one of the differences between Debian  and ubuntu is that ubuntu has a 6 month release cycle, so you get a reasonably up-to-date gnome.
the release stable versions of Ubuntu every 6 months. you can stick with your version for about 1 year of official support or you can choose to upgrade to a new stable version.
gutsy gibbon (what I have) uses gnome 2.20.0
the last 2 version of Ubuntu are fiesty fawn and gutsy gibbon (now in beta)
type 'more /etc/lsb-release'
did you include the ' (single quote)? if so, try with out them.
so you typed :        more /etc/lsb-release                  and no output?
so what did it say?
so you are using the last stable release = fiesty
sure. I am running the next stable release,, now in beta, gutsy.
one of the wonders of Debian and its children is 'apt', it alone make upgrading your distro easy.
is certainly better to have a firewall, but for the most part there is not linux 'virus' and if there was one, its not easy to catch.
I like 'shorewall' but there are others.
most folks who have DSL or cable, have a 'modem' that has a built-in firewall, at least some do, so that is some protection.
the 'application' menu has an option ''add/remove'. choose this to install software
